Henry, you could have also given the example of why a setting sun is red. Because the light has to travel through more atmosphere, while the red light is not filtered like the blue light.

This is not exactly correct. Because the sun is so dense and large, light can only pass a short distance (generally less than a centimeter) without being refracted. As a result, individual photons usually spend around a million years inside the sun before reaching the surface and being emitted. Thus we cannot "see" into the core of the sun. The actual reason the sun looks brighter near the center is more complicated and requires a lot of math to explain.

I know this is nick-picking but....  humans don't project vision abilities from their eye.  You got it completely backward.  What it is, is that path of light from stuff is block less when it has less to go through.  Also the bit with the candles, and at the same time the sun, is light ray stacking,  you get the same effect when you point more then one directional light source on to a single spot.    Eyes are like cameras and they open up to let light fall in to the back of them.    That is why you need to use a sun filter, to cut the percentage of light rays coming from the sun or else you would have more rays hitting the back of your eye then what the cells can handle.

The sun gets colder at greater distances from the core until it reaches the chromosphere, at 4500 K. After that, it heats up in the transition zone and corona. If those areas were thicker, and thus brighter (they would emit the same amount of light per gram of material, but there would be more material), the limb darkening phenomenon described would be applicable at certain angles, but would cause brightening at others.
